paragraphs: the COVID-19 pandemic gave rise to an unprecedented surge in misinformation.
this study explores factors driving COVID-19 misinformation, its spread via social media, its impact on public health, the effectiveness of mitigation efforts
misinformation spreads through a structured process with multiple stages.
misinformation spreads faster than factual content.
misinformation enters echo chambers as people mainly interact with like-minded individuals.
real-time fact-checking, algorithm adjustments, and trusted messengers can help correct falsehoods.
if unchecked, false narratives continue to spread.

paragraphs: the aim of this systematic review is to synthesize the existing literature on the infodemic during the COVID-19 pandemic.
review adheres to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses 2020 and the Quality of Reporting of
studies published between December 2019 and December 2024 were included if they focused specifically on COVID-19-related misinformation causes, spread, impacts
a comprehensive search was conducted across PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, and Google Scholar using MeSH terms and keywords related to COVI
two independent researchers coded study characteristics into seven themes: role of digital platforms in amplifying misinformation; interventions to combat infodemic; trusted
the AMSTAR 2 tool appraised the quality of included studies across 16 domains.
records identified (n=495 after duplicates removed) were screened.
a narrative synthesis categorized findings into misinformation spread, impact, and mitigation.
social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, YouTube) emerged as dominant vectors for misinformation.
algorithmic biases prioritize engagement over accuracy, favoring emotionally charged misinformation.
reactive measures (fact-checking, content moderation) often lag behind rapid spread.
Generative AI and deepfakes exacerbate misinformation challenges.
